title: 115_hr1790
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Health Care Trust Fund Act". Congress acknowledges the unpredictable nature of war and the long-term health care costs associated with conflicts. An independent estimate predicts that the costs for health care and disability compensation related to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan will exceed $970 billion over the next few decades. This is supported by the increasing treatment costs for conditions like Agent Orange exposure in Vietnam Veterans, Gulf War Syndrome in Gulf War Veterans, and burn pit exposure in Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans. Addressing these costs now ensures that Congress considers them when deciding on military actions. The use of military force ensures our Nation can better address the long-term health care needs of veterans. SEC. 3. WAR TRUST FUNDS. Section 119 of title 38, United States Code, establishes war trust funds in the General Fund of the Treasury for each war. Funds collected through the Internal Revenue Code related to the war are deposited into the fund and can be used for veterans' hospital care, disability compensation, and other benefits during that war. The Secretary can determine other programs and benefits related to veterans' health care. If multiple wars occur concurrently, separate trust funds are established for each war. Reports must be submitted to relevant committees every 30 days after the first withdrawal from a trust fund, detailing the use of the withdrawn amounts. The Comptroller General conducts audits of financial statements for funds withdrawn by the Secretary for veterans' programs. The term 'war' is defined in the section to include wars declared by Congress or authorized under the War Powers Resolution. The text discusses the War Powers Resolution, Authorization for Use of Military Force, and other authorizations for military force enacted after a certain date. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. SEC. 4. WAR TAX. A new part VII - War Tax is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, imposing a tax on covered individuals for each war occurring during the taxable year. The tax rates based on adjusted gross income range from $25 to $1,000. The term 'war' is defined as any use of the Armed Forces under specific conditions. The tax imposed under this section is based on adjusted gross income and ranges from $25 to $1,000. The term 'war' is defined as any use of the Armed Forces under specific conditions. The Secretary will enumerate each war with respect to which a tax is imposed for any taxable year. The tax imposed under this section is not treated as a tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes. The tax imposed under this section is not considered a tax under this chapter for certain purposes. The amendment made by subsection (a) is not a change in tax rate for section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A clerical amendment is made to the table of parts for subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section regarding the War Tax apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
